DEATH OF REV. CHARLES FOX.--Rev. CHARLES Fox died at Humtramack, yesterday morning at 4 o'clock, after a brief illness. Mr. Fox was by birth an Englishman, and was educated for the Episcopal Church. Some years ago he was assistant rector of St. Paul's Church in this city, from which post to removed to Gross Isle, where he resided until last Spring, when, his dwelling being destroyed by fire, he removed a Hamtramck.

The funeral of Miss. FILLMORE took place this morning. It was attended by a large concourse of the leading citizens. More deep felt and general grief has been seldom witnessed, than was manifested throughout the city. Miss. FILLMORE was exceedingly amiable in her disposition, and was beloved by everybody.

FATAL ACCIDENT AT CLIFTON.--A short distance from the shore, opposite Clifton, a resident of the village, named MULLAGH, was drowned on Thursday afternoon, while bathing. He was unable to swim, and, falling into deep water from a rock which he had ascended on the side where the water was shallow, he was not seen to rise again. Search has been made for his body--as yet without success.

HORRIBLE ACCIDENT.--We are just informed of a dreadful accident which occurred yesterday evening at the Portage tunnel. It appears that the workmen were being brought up the shait, which is sunk to the depth of 180 feet. The men attached to the rope were drawn up among the shives at the top of the windlass; two men dropped off and fell into the shaft. killing them instantly.

ARREST OF DESERTERS AND ROBBERS.--About a fortnight ago the Public Treasury at Sydney, C. B., was entered and robbed by two soldiers of the British Army, named URIAH PRITCHARD and THOMAS CAREY, of about $700 in gold and silver, with which they deserted to this country.

DEATH OF A PROMINENT NEW-HAMPSHIRE MAN.--We learn by a private telegraphic dispatch, that JOSEPH STEPHENS ABBOT, Esq.; of Concord, N. H., died of Cholera at New-York City last night. His age was upwards of 60 years. Mr. ABBOT was the founder of the carriage-building business in Concord some forty years since, when there were but few establishments in the whole country, and has continued identified with it steadily from that time till the present.

WELL DONE FOR MISSISSIPPI -- NOVEL WAY TO KILL FLEAS. -- A certain academy in Clarke County, Mississippi, had been the resort of a parcel of hogs, under whose structure they look shelter from in-element weather. In course of time the fleas because so very numerous, and so annoyed the students as to cause the teachers to call together the trustees, to devise ways and means to get clear of this troublesome vermin.

A sudden and violent sickness broke out in the State Prison last night. As we learn the facts from the proper sources they are as follows: At about 11 o'clock the Deputy Warden, Mr. WALKER was called to the cell of PETER YORK, the colored man in prison for life for murder committed in Ann-street, and found him apparently in the last stages of cholera, with scarcely any pulse, and his extremities quite cold.

A SAD STORY.-- The following extraordinary case occurred in Mississippi under the slave laws of that State: "A Planter was afflicted with a loathsome disease. So offensive were his aleers that he was deserted by his white friends; and, while thus afflicted and forsaken, a girl, whom he owned as a slave, kindly and patiently waited upon him, dressed his ulcers, cleansed his person, and watched over him until he eventually recovered.

A fire broke out yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock, in the stone yard of Messrs. HENDERSON WILLSON, on Washington-street, between Wayne and Steuben-Streets, which was the most destructive that has ever occurred in Jersey City. The Fire Department were soon at work, but the fire spread with great rapidity, and was not got under until two entire blocks and the half of another bounded by Washington, Wayne, Steuben and Greene-streets, were destroyed.

IN A HURRY.--A lad entered a store in South Pearl-street, yesterday, seized a piece of calico with the remark, "Mother will pay for this in the morning," and darted out in an instant. The storekeeper stood for a moment astonished at the rather abrupt proceeding, but soon started in pursuit and overtook the boy, nearly frightening him to death.

The Presbyterian Assembly has just closed its annual sittings in Belfast, and has appointed its next meeting, July, 1855, in Dublin. Until of late, its congregations were almost all in Ulster, and Belfast was its head-quarters. But its congregations are multiplying in all the provinces. From five, the number that formed the first Presbytery, they have increased to considerably more than five hundred.

Nahant consists of two peninsular islands, called Great Nahant and Little Nahant. The aboriginal squatters, whom the Anglo-Saxons spirited away, used to call the place Nahanteu, or the Twins; the islands being connected together, unlike the Twins of Siam--by a rope of sand. The first settlers used to speak of the Nahants. Great Nahant is about two miles long and half a mile wide.

GIGANTIC STATUE TO SHAKSPEARE.--Signor CHARDIGNI has made public, through the Journal of the Society of Arts, a proposal for erecting a gigantic statue of SHAKSPEARE. Signor CHARDIGNI proposes that the statue should be 100 feet high, of cast iron, formed by a new process, which he has invented. In the statue it is proposed to have three floors, with a staircase for ascending to the top or head of the monument.

Mr STEVENS' Yacht, the Maria, has won the race and the five hundred dollar cup. The wind was fair, and the sea moderate. The distance sailed was forty miles, which the Maria made in about five hours. She turned the stake-boat at 20 minutes to 1 o'clock, P.M. the yacht Julia came in second, the haze third. The Una is said to stand the fourth in the race.

Paper made from wood, as a substitute for rags, appears to be coming into use, with the prospect of effecting a large saving for newspaper publishers. It is firm and smooth, but is deficient in fineness of texture and in general appearance, compared with the ordinary kind.

The Avenue A and Jersey City stages advertise to carry passengers after Monday next for four cents. So we go. So many of the stages now charge three cents only that some of the six-cent lines have to keep notices posted that their fare is six cents yet. A year ago the Fourth-avenue cars charged sixpence, now they are down to five.

MURDER OF A PLAYMATE BY A LITTLE BOY.--The Galena Advertiser notes the fact that a lad names GEORGE JACKSON, aged twelve years, was committed to jail in this city, a day or two since, for the murder of a playmate, called ELIAS HORN, aged sixteen. Both boys were residents of Millville, in this county. The two went to Apple River together, and JACKSON returned alone.

NEVER "HOPE YOU DON'T INTRUDE."--Reader, a word, a serious, sober heart-full word. This is it : Never think you don't intrude. You do. You pop into a parlor, perhaps. There sits in the twilight and bliss, lounging on a sofa, a loving couple. Of course you hope you don't intrude. But you do, though. You drop into an editorial room. Business is driving.

What the President would have done with the ten millions, if Congress had given him that sum to be used at his discretion, in measures concerning Cuba, is a matter of inquiry. To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I have just received from a passenger in the cars, the Portland Advertiser of this morning, with the enclosed notice of the detection and arrest of the most important gang of counterfeiters probably ever broken up on this Continent. SUMNER BURNHAM, Esq., the agent of the American banks referred to, deserves the highest credit for his skillful and effective agency in this bold enterprise.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: I thank your correspondent "F.," for his suggestion, that a School Association for Eastern New-York ought to be formed, though some of his reasons have no weight with me, I have no fault to find with the "State" Association. The insufficient supply of Croton Water during the Summer months, owing to the large quantites used for sprinkling the streets and for extinguishing tires, has been a cause of serious complaint among a large class of our citizens.

A young Irishman, named MICHAEL HENRY MOONEY, has been arrested in this City one charge of robbing a mercantile house in Liverpool of [pound]150. He has fully confessed his guilt, and will return to England. JOHN P. SMITH, a wealthy merchant of Wrightsville, Va., fell dead of apoplexy, in a store where he was making purchases.

Fugitive Excitement. There was considerable excitement in Jersey City on Wednesday evening and yesterday morning, relative to a colored lad, who was arrested, and who, it was rumored, was a fugitive slave. A large number of persons took a lively interest in the matter.

A man by the name of STARKIE, who occupied a farm adjacent to the Sahne coal mines, had lost several chickens, and his suspicions rested naturally upon the miners, a great number of whom are generally employed by the Company. By the influence of his wife, it seems STARKIE'S suspicious were peculiarly directed toward the unfortunate deceased.

We find it announced in the Evangelist of last week, that at the late Commencement a Wabash College, Indiana. "the honorary degree of Doctor of Divinity was conferred on Rev. JOSHUA LEAVATT, one of the editors of The Independent." "Honor to whom honor is due."

We rejoice that we can now announce an entire cession of the Cholera in our village. We make this statement from information derived from the only true sources, viz.: The records of the Board of Health and of the Sexion. From these it appears, that during the last eight days, we have had but two deaths, both children, one two years and the other seven months old.

Incendiary Fire. At an early hour yesterday morning flames were seen issuing from the basement window of a wooden house on Adelphi-street, near Flushing-avenue, Brooklyn. Engine Company No. 9 extinguished the fire before much damage occurred.

The Anti-Nebraska meeting in the Grove was called to order at 11 o'clock this morning, by CALVIN PEPPER. R. N. HAVENS, of New-York, was chosen President. C. P. WILLIAMS, of Albany, Professor McCoy, of Saratoga, Secretaries; and EDWARD C. DELAVAN, J. N. KNAPP, of Kings, W. C. RUSSELL, WM. RICHARDSON, of Albany, JAMES M. BOYD, DANIEL P. WOOD, of Onondaga, Vice-Presidents.

ACCIDENTS.--A teamster named JOHN BROWN, living in Newark, had his leg broken on Wednesday by a roll of leather falling upon it from a wagon, on the New-York side of the ferry...Late on Tuesday night, as an elderly gentleman, linving in Jersey-avenue, was stepping from the cars of the New-York and Erie Railroad train at the depot, he slipped and fell, fracturing his thigh bone.

The Episcopal Convention for the Western Diocese of New-York, met in this city yesterday, Bishop DE LANCEY presiding. About 50 of the clergy and 79 of the laity, representing fifty-two parishes, are in attendance. The commencement of the Collegiate Department of Madison University, a Baptist Institution, was held yesterday at Hamilton, Madison County.

A POLICEMAN ARRESTED BY A POLICEMAN.--On Wednesday morning while Officer JAS. CALHOUN, of the Second Ward Police, Williamsburg, was proceeding with a wagon load of prisoners from Williamsburg to Brooklyn, he was arrested in Flushing avenue, by Officer NOLAN, of the Fourth District Police, Brooklyn, on a charge of violating a city ordinance by driving over the sidewalk.

Last night the magazine situated on the Maysville and Lexington turnpike road at the lower end of the city, was fired by miscreants unknown, and its contents, eight hundred kegs of blasung and rifle powder, were burned, causing a terrific explosion and great destruction of property. In the neighborhood of the magazine fired were two other magazines containing powder which were blown up. and a part of the powder it is supposed burned.

ACCIDENT AND DEATH--We regret to learn that JACOB C. COOPER, a conductor of a gravel train on the Watertown and Rome Railroad, was so seriously injured on Tuesday last that be died the same night. He was engaged at Adams Centre in switching some cars from one track to the other, and was standing on the engine step as the train was backing near the point where the tracks connected.

DEATH OF HENRY BIBB.--We are pained to learn of the death of HENRY BIBB, editor of the Voice of the Fugitive. He died at Windsor, Canada West, on the 1st inst., aged 39 years. His life was on eventful one. Born a slave in Kentucky, he toiled in servitude for twenty-five years, when he effected his own emancipation, and for ten years past has labored diligently and faithfully as an Anti-Slavery editor and lecturer.

Returns received here from Iowa render it certain that GEIMES, Whig, is elected Governor by 3,000 majority. THORRINGTON, Whig, is elected to Congress in the Dubuque District by 1,500 majority over HEMPSTEAD, Democrat. The Legislature is Whig and Anti-Nebraska by a large majority, in both branches.

The annual Commencement exercises of this Institution have been largely attended, and have passed of with the usual variety of good, bad and indifferent performances. On account of the illness of President HOPKINS, the Baccalaureate Sermon was dispensed with on Sunday, and insured thereof, Rev. Dr. BETHUNE, of Brooklyn, delivered an able and interesting discourse.

A number of emigrant ships crowded in opposite Quarantine, on Thursday, bringing in between seventeen and eighteen hundred emigrants; and one vessel (theManhattam,) with half the entire number. The Manhattan left this port upon her last trip two months and seventeen days since. On her trip from Liverpool, made in twenty-nine days, she had 874 passengers on board.

It has been already stated that a sparring-match was made between JEMMY TRAINOR and PETER McDERMOTT, to fight a battle on the 12th of September. The parties were to meet again to sing articles, , but in the meantime the parents of McDERMOTT interfered in the matter, and he was compelled to give up the idea of match-making for the present.

GOOD STORIES.--Hon. PELEG W. CHANDLER in his speech at the Whig Convention, yesterday, told the following capital stories, illustrative of recent political movements. One was of an old man in Bangor, who would steal, but at the same time a man of his word. He was one day engaged to help unload a cargo of fish, on condition that he should have nine of them if he would not steal any.

The wind being light yesterday, the Regatla at New London came off to day. Twenty boats started. The Restless, of Greenport, length 29 feet 4 inches, came in first. The Gohlep Eagle of New-London, length 30 feet, came in second. The Restless started at 12 o'clock 20 minutes 30 seconds; came in 2 o'clock 38 minutes.

We publish reports showing that Iowa has elected a Whig Governor by a large majority, and also a strong Whig and Anti-Nebraska Legislature. What are called the regular Democrats of the first Congressional District of Maine, met in Convention yesterday, when Mr. McDONALD, the present member for the District who voted for the Nebraska bill, did not receive a single vote.

Navy-Yard Affairs. The frigate Independence will be taken into the Dry Dock to have her bottom examined on Tuesday next. She will be put into commission on the 1st of September, and it is expected that she will sail for the Pacific about the middle of September. She will soon have her complement of seamen.

A DARING ATTEMPT.--HENRY GRANCE, an Englishman, aged twenty years, or thereabouts, and an upholsterer by trade, arrived in this city lately, and took lodgings at the sailor's boarding house of MICHAEL QUINN, in Bedon's Alley. About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, be entered the proprietor's private room for the purpose of robbery, but had not executed his scheme before the proprietor accidentally entered and interrupted him.

YELLOW FEVER AT MOBILE.--There were 24 deaths at Mobile, during the week ending Aug. 12, 2 of which were of yellow fever. The Mobile Advertiser of the 13th says, in reference to them: One of them belonged to the crew of the ship Aymar, from Matanzas, which, our readers will remember, arrived some weeks since in the Lower bay with yellow fever on board.

The Foreign Mail, by the America arrived at an early hour last evening, and from them we publish a variety of extracts which, though not of extraordinary importance, are of considerable interest. The London payers contain but little news of interest additioanl to that telegraphed from Halifax.

The bark Aaron J. Hartry arrived here to-day from Pori-an-Prince. She brings with her JOHN MILLER, who was sent home by the United States Consul, at his own request, to stand a trial for the murder of a woodcutter named MYERS, whom he killed in the woods in Washington Township, Morris County, New-Jersey, about ten months since.

STATISTICS OF SUICIDE--We learn from Galignant's Messenger that the French Ministry of Justice has published on official return of the number of suicides which have taken place in France in the course of twenty-seven years.

Still, as the hotels here are this year crowded excessively, it is a pretty sure index that the place is becoming more and more popular.

ACCIDENT TO THE OPERA COMPANY--On the arrival of the New-York steamboat train this morning, the members of the Italian opera troupe, seventeen in number, took a coach to be conveyed to the Revere House. At the corner of Beach and Kingston streets the coach came in collision with a team, and upset, throwing the outside passengers upon the sidewalk, but they escaped material injury.

The United States steamship San Jacinto, Capt. STRIELING, which left Philadelphia on Saturday last for a cruise in the Baltic, put into this port to-day for repairs. A bad break occurred Saturday morning in a sewer just completed in Charlton-street, running underneath the track of the Sixth-avenue Railroad in Varick-street. The next time seen they were disputing, KING on his horse, and DOUGHERTY on the ground, holding KING'S horse by bridle.

While WELLINGTON was in the Peninsula, from 1808 until 1814, he had the good sense not to give the army which he commanded any trouble about costume. Provided that they kept their powder dry and their arms in good fighting order, he did not annoy them by absurd orders respecting dress. Indeed, it would have been almost useless to have done so.

MURDER OF CAPTAIN R. M. STROTHER.--Reports were brought to this city yesterday of the death of Captain R. M. STROTHER, caused by the deliberate discharge of the contents of a gun in the hands of Captain HARRIS, in command of the stem-wheel steamer Michigan.

By the arrival of the steamship Europa, at Halifax, we are in possession of one week's later news from Europe. The working of the telegraph, however, having been interrupted, our report is not as full as desirable. On the 16th, we are informed, Bomarsund surrendered, and 2,000 Russians were taken prisoners. The French lost 100, and had 60 men killed. The Austrians are still entering Wallachia.

CELEBRATION OF THE INTRODUCTION OF WATER.--Tuesday, October 3, is the day appointed for the celebration of the introducton of Rassaic water into Jersey City--us that work is now completed and in operation. The day will be celebrated by the Fire Department of Jersey City, which will then have its first annual parade. Hereafter, the same event will be celebrated by the firemen's annual parade.

The Royal Mail steamship Europa, Captain SHANNON, from Liverpool on the afternoon of Saturday, the 19th inst., arrived at this port shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon. The Collins steamship Pacific, from New-York on the 5th inst., arrived at Liverpool at 3 o'clock P.M. on the 15th, making the passage in 9 days and 22 hours mean time.

From the Marseilles (France) Paper. Yesterday one of our railroad cars was the scene of a domestic drama, the circumstances of which were as follows: A very young and pretty girl elegantly dressed, was seated near a young man whose attitude and looks indicated an affection more tender than that of a brother or a cousin. Suddenly they both turned pale and appeared greatly agitated.

BATTLE OF BLADENSBURG.--Entry years age (yesterday) was fought the battle of Bladensburg, Maryland. The British on that occasion, from the vast superiority of their numbers, were victorious; but their loss in killed and wounded was 219, white that of the Americans was but 80. The British entered the city of Washington at 8 o'clock in the evening.

A fresh Revolution seems to be in full blast on our Southwestern frontier. From our Correspondence from that quarter, published in another column, it will be seen that a battle was fought not far from Matamoras on the 13th ult, between the insurgents and the Government troops, in which the former, commanded by CAPISTRAN and numbering 250, were victorious.

On the 13th inst., not far from Matamoras, the first pitched battle in this vicinity, between the Insurgents and the Government troops, took place. The former were commanded by MACEDONIO CAPISTRAN, and numbered 250,--and the latter 180, commanded by Colonel CRUZ. The result was a signal victory for CAPISTRAN, who killed five officers and twenty men of his opponents, without sustaining any loss whatever himself.

I have received late items of news from Utah and New-Mexico. A party arrived at Independence from Utah some days ago. IRISH ROW ON THE SOUTH COVE.--Yesterday afternoon Officer HUNKINS arrested a noisy and disorderly Irishman near the Old colony depot, and as he was taking him to the lock-up, he was beset by the clan of the neighborhood, and the prisoner was violently rescued, after a hard and severe fight, in which Mr. HUNKINS was struck in the back of the neck with a brick-bat, knocked down, and bruised and battered generally.

A young man named SHORT, clerk in a dry goods store in this city, and a young lawyer named PLACOCK, from Chicago, fought a duel in Kentucky, yesterday. On the second round, SHORT was fatally wounded in the left breast. They fought about a young girl to whom SHORT was engaged.

The Roman Catholic Bishop of St. John, New-Brunswick, who arrived in this City a day or two since, gives an appalling account of the manner in which the population of that town has been decimated by Cholera. Within a short period a thousand of the inhabitants have been cut off, and seven hundred and fifty orphan children have been left without friends of kindred.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--SHERIDAN'S Comedy of the "Rivals" was produced here last evening, and as is usual with that play, attracted a fair audience, notwithstanding the almost insupportable heat of the weather. The Comedy introduced us to a new artist--a Mr. STODDARD, from one of the Scotch theatres.

A regular meeting of the Farmer' Club was held on Tuesday. JAMES G. SAWKINS, Esq., made some remarks upon the general agricultural growth and condition of Australia. Mr. SAWKINS spoke of the New-Zealand flax. He said there was nowhere produced a stronger and better material. The New-Zealanders, he remarked, made all their fishing-lines of flax.

THE SILENT WOMAN.-Madame RIGHTER, the wife of a law officer at Versailles, while talking in the presence of a numerous party, dropped some remarks which were out of place, dropped some remarks which were out of place, though not important. Her husband reprimanded her before the whole company, saying: "Silonce, Madame, you are a fool!" She lived twenty or thirty years afterwards and never uttered a single word, even to her children.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: Why do you not advocate the use of standard measures by all dealers in fruit or vegetables, whether in or out of our markets? Potatoes and peaches are now sold by the basket; each dealer has baskets to suit himself. The poor suffer immensely by this mode.

The investigation into the causes of the riot in Newark was commenced yesterday, and will be continued this morning. The greatest excitement prevails in Newark in relation to this affair. The investigation bids fair to be prolonged even beyond to-day.

COMMENDABLE COURTESY.--We are gratified to be able to record an instance of magnanimity, growing out of the late fire. Our lilliputian friend, Gen. Gifford, having learned that Geo. H. Walker had been so unfortunate as to lose most of his clothes in the United States Hotel, with his usual polite consideration, addressed the colossal Colonel a note, kindly tendering the use of his wardrobe.

The bark Charles E. Lex arrived at this port yesterday from Port-an-Prince, which place she left on the 18th ult. We are indebted to her master, Capt HENRY HARPER, for the statement of the latest news. It will he perceived that he attributes the uneasiness of the Emperor and his subjects to the diplomatic intrigues of the United States with the Dominican Republic.

The present population of Kentucky may be put down at 850,000 whites, and 230,00 blacks. The average of marriages is about one to every 102 whites. In particular parts of the State, marriages have been much greater than in others. The great Trotting Match for a purse and stake of $3,000, between several celebrated horses, has been looked for with considerable interest. It was witnessed yesterday by an audience of some five thousand persons, from New-York and elsewhere.

We are gratified to learn that the Freshman class just beginning its course at Harvard College is extraordinarily large, numbering, we believe, one hundred and five. Besides these, there have been accessions to the other classes of students admitted to an advanced standing. The annual foot-ball match upon the Delta took place last evening, the first Monday of the term, in accordance with the time honored custom.

The Massachusetts Republican State Convention met in this place to-day, and was very fully attended from all sections of the State. J. J. ANDREW, of Hingham, was temporary Chairman, and ROBERT RANTOUL, of Beverly, elected to be the permanent President.

For some time past several farmers in Southampton have been missing sheep from their flocks, and in some instances fifteen or twenty have mysteriously disappeared. On searching the woods many of the carcasses have been found drawn into the under brush and covered with leaves, the blood of each having been sucked out through a single wound in the neck.

The events of the last week have introduced a new epoch in the political history of Canada. Mr. HINCKS, who has held the reins of power for the last seven years, has been defeated on six divisions in the new Parliament, and with his colleagues resigned office, and already a new Administration has been formed, with Sir ALLAN McNAB, the recognized leader of Upper Canada Toryism, at its head.

MURDER.--A woman named McMAHON, residing in North First-street, Troy, was found floating in the river Saturday morning, near the steamboat landing, feet of Albany-street. Upon examination marks of violence were found on the body. She left her house Thursday noon, and undoubtedly was badly beaten and then thrown into the river Friday night.

A GLOOMY SABBATH.--Yesterday was, perhaps, the gloomiest Sunday that most persons in our community have ever spent. The churches were opened, but their congregations were exceedingly thin, and an aspect of anxiety and dejection was visible on every face. The exercises were brief, but solemn and impressive.

THE NEW-YORK THEATRE, on the site of the old Metropolitan Hall, opens to night. The performances commence with an original prize address, written by JONAS B. PHILLIPS, and to be delivered by the manager, HARRY EYTINGE. The dramatic company will then be introduced, and sing, with full orchestral accompaniment, the National Anthem.

THE BURNT DISTRICT.--We passed round the scene of the late disastrous fire again yesterday, and were glad to see that the task of clearing the rains, repairing and rebuilding was being prosecuted with all practicable speed and energy.

RAFT OF LUMBER LOST.--A large raft of lumber which left New-York on Friday afternoon, in tow of a steamer, commenced breaking up as it passed to Hurigate, and the steamer made a steamer, and the raft was reconstructed, as it was supposed securely, but in the storm of Saturday it again began to separate, and when the steamboat arrived at Connection river, only three sticks of timber remained attached.

The publication of names, purporting to be a list of Know-Nothings, has engendered much bitterness in the community. It is threatened that a publication of other Ward lists will be made. The excitement is increasing, but may be allayed, when the fact is generally understood that these lists are the result of an individual canvass of the voting lists, and embrace the names of the probable votes for TOWERS at the late Municipal Election.

A few cases of cholera have lately appeared on the Island; one of the principal medical officials, under the Emigration Commissioners, recently suffered an attack at Tompkinsville, and is now slowly recovering.

Every friend of Deaf-Mute instruction in this country will regret to hear of the death of Mr. LUZERNE RAE, of the American Asylum at Hartford. The event took place on Friday, and was remarkably sudden. Mr. RAE had suffered for a considerable time under attacks of nervous debility, and at intervals was disagreeably affected.

Yesterday was the commencement of the regular Fall meeting of the National Jockey Club, and as two races were positively announced to take place, the attendance on the Course was much more numerous than that of any day last week. The track was in excellent order, although the day was not well calculated for fast time, a strong wind blowing over it and necessarily impeding the speed of the horses.

The New-Orleans papers to hand this morning mention that the riot in that city originated in a quarrel between the citizens and some watchmen, the latter being mostly Irishmen. This mysterious and destructive disease has suddenly visited us. Since its first advent into this country, this city and region have been remarkably exempt from its ravages. It has at no time, except probably in 1832, assumed a general epidemic form. It has broken out suddenly in localities and neighborhoods, and as suddenly subsided.

Within the last few years we have had several popular demonstrations on a scale of considerable magnitude. No one can question that incidental evils have grown out of them. WILLIAM BROCKEDON died in London on the 29th ult., after a long and painful illnesss, at the age of sixty-six. This gentleman is principally known by his works on Italy and the Passes of the Apls--large and handsome books profusely illustrated by his own pencil. They were among the earliest of our illustrated books of travels. Mr. BROCKEDON published also Excursione in the Alps and a Road-Book from London to Naples.

The Bath (Mc,) Mirror of Sept. 20 states that there has been some excitement in that city relative to a fugitive slave on board the bark Franklin at that port, from Jacksonville. The Franklin put into Holmes' Hole on the 19th, and notified the Customs that he had a fugitive slave on board. The authorities at Jacksonville were notified by telegraph, and the authorities at Washington also.

SLAVE CASE IN CINCINNATI.--A few days since we published a statement that two slaves, a father and son, claimed by HENRY SUMPTALL, of Jefferson County, Ky., had made their escape from their master. The fugitives were pursued to this city, and were apprehended near Cumminsville. The pursuers chased them to College Hill, where GEORGE, the boy, was captured.

Hudson County Circuit and Court of Oyer and Terminer. This morning the September term of the Circuit Court and Court of Oyer and Terminer, will commence at the Court-house at Bergen Five Corners. There will be a heavy civil calendar and a large amount of criminal business, the County jail being full. A great majority of the cases are assault and battery. There are no cases of capital offence to be tried.

The Brooklyn Fire Department. Some weeks since, most of the respectable fire companies in Brooklyn notified the Common Council of their intention not to run to fires in the Second District unless there was something done to protect them from the assaults of a lawless gang of rowdies in that section of the city, who had assailed them with stones and brickbats on nearly every visit to the Second District, for months past.

The School at North Stonington, Connecticut, under charge of Mr. BROWN, as Principal, closed the public examination on Tuesday, 19th instant. Two Frenchmen took lodgings at a small hotel in Dock-street last night, and retired atten o'clock. One of them left this morning, and this afternoon his comrade was found in the room which they jointly occupied, his brains blown out and his pockets rifled.

JAMES MADISON BICKFORD, the murderer of JOHN B. SECOR, was yesterday at noon executed in pursuance of his sentence in the yard adjoining the County jail in this village. His accomplice, THOMAS COOK, obtained, through the exertions of the public officers and others, a communication of his punishment to imprisonment for life, and was sent last week to Clinton Prison, Denemora.

Epispocal Convention. The Annual Diocesan Convention commences its sessions at St. John's Chapel at 10 o'clock this morning. The interest which attaches to this Convention is peculiar. The recent demise of Bishop WAINWRIGHT will cause a renewal of the contests for and against the restoration of Bishop ONDERDONK, who has now been suspended from his ecclesiastical functions for a period of eight or nine years.

Last evening about 6 o'clock, as the 5 1/2 train on the Long Island Railroad, from the Union Race Course, was entering the tunnel in Atlantic-street, Brooklyn, a man attempted to leap from the forward car, when he fell upon the track and the whole train passed over him, splitting his head completely open, breaking one arm and one leg, mangling the body in a shocking manner.

SIR: On this day, sixty-two years ago, a great act was accomplished, and its memory is sacred to all republicans throughout the world. The French National Convention sat on the 2d of September, 1792, in solemn majesty, and proclaimed, in its sovereign power, that Monarchy was abolished and that France had become a Republic.

THE KANSAS SEAL--We have just seen the seal of the Territory of Kansas, engraved by ROBERT LOVETT, of Philadelphia, according to the design of Gov. REEDER. It consists of a shield with two supporters and surmounted by a scroll motto, and is emblematic of the life of the pioneer and the agriculturist.

GENERAL CASS DEFINING HIS POSITION.--It is the fashion of the day to disparage the present race of public men. This, like every other fashion, may be carried to a ridiculous and absurd extreme, but there is unquestionably some cause for lament over the decay of virtue and talent among those who rule the councils of the country.

HORRIBLE DEATH FROM HYDROPHOBIA.--LAWRENCE MYERS, residing on Sixth.street, below Carolina, was bitten by a dog belonging to the family, some six or seven weeks since. About a week ago he exhibited symptoms of hydrophobia. Dr. HAWLEY was called in, and at his request Drs. WIHTE, FLINT, and one or two more of our most eminent physicians were consulted and went to see MYERS.

Judge JOHN PURVIANCE, of Baltimore, died in that city on the 22d inst., at the age of 81 years. he presided as Judge of Baltimore County Court, embracing one of the Juticial Districts of Maryland, for nearly thirty years, and filled the office until removed-some two years ago by the new Constitution. A pure and unsullied life is his highest eulogy.

Last night, the steamer E. K. Collins left this port between 10 and 11 o'clock with a large number of passengers on board, bound from the Sault St. Marie to Cleveland. SMART GIRLS.--A couple of girls were arrested in Nashua a few days since for some sort of impropriety, and ordered to Amherst jail. Before leaving, they escaped from their keepers once, but were soon retaken.

Additional particulars of the loss of the Arctic were received in this City yesterday. The latest intelligence is confirmatory of the leading facts already published, but we have the satisfaction of being able to announce that the loss of life is considerably less than was at first reported. Doubts still exist, however, in regard to the great majority of the Arctic's passengers; the fate of three boats being as yet wholly unknown.

This line steamer was burned near Malden, last evening, between the hours of 10 and 11 o'clock. She was on her return trip from the "Soo" to Cleveland, had no freight on board, and but few passengers. She was managed by one of the best crews on the lakes, and enjoyed as high a reputation for speed, safety and comfort, as any beat on the Western waters.

We regret to learn that Rev. JOHN H. HANSON, Assistant Minister of Calvary Church, in this City, died on Monday at his residence. His remains were interred on Wednesday in Trinity Cemetery. Mr. Hanson was well known as the author of a work lately published by PUTNAM, tending to establish the identity of Rev. ELEAZAR WILLIAMS with the missing Dauphin of France.

We have further intelligence of interest from the scene of the Arctic's disaster. The vessel which ran into her proves to have been the Vesta, a French screw steamer, and instead of going down bows foremost, as was at first reported, she reached St. Johns in safety on the 30th, three days after the collision, having on board thirty-one of the Arctic's CREW, which she picked up at the times of the catastrophe.

He was a native of Salem, where be leaves a family.

NUMBER OF THE INMATES OF LUNATIC ASYLUMS.-At the period of the Census there were in the various Lunatic Asylums and other institutions for the reception of the insane in Great Britain, 18,803 persons; 8,999 males and 9,804 females. The collective wisdom of Canada, so far as residing in her Parliament, has during the last fortnight been almost exclusively devoted to our two great questions, of the Clergy Reserves in Upper Canada. and the Seignorial Tenure in Lower Canada. An ex-policeman of German birth, named FREED, of the Seventeenth Ward, attempted suicide on Thursday night, in the Station-house, by taking laudanum. The bark Spencer Kirby, JOHN THECARLIN master, parted her chain and went ashore at Salt Cay Oct. 28, during a heavy squall, which caused the wind to shift suddenly and she became a total wreck. A Railroad Convention was held at Salisbury, North Carolina, on the 2d instant Resolutions were adopted in favor of a general system of Internal improvements and of the State subscribing for two-thirds of the capital stock of such works as are calculated to develop its resource. KIDNAPPING.--On Sunday evening last, a colored woman, named JANE MOOKE of this city, was called to her door, knocked down, placed in a carriage, and lodged in jail in Covington, on the preference that she was a fugitive slave, owned in Maysville, Ky. The woman was taken by some of her friends before Mayor FOLEY, of Covington, and her freedom established.

STARTING DEVELOPMENTS.--The attempted robbery of the County Treasurer's office on last Thursday night, seems to have been but one of a series of robberies which were to have been perpetrated during the Full and Winter. The arrest of JAMES W. FITZOERALD, (who is lying in jail under $2,000 bonds,) and the revelations of SAMUEL BAILEY, (who turned State's evidence,) have probably broken up the gang and prevented the crimes that would otherwise have been committed.

THE BEAR.--Dr. SANBORN, of Andover, ably defends the beard in a late number of the Boston Medical and Surgical Journal. He takes the ground that the custom of shaving the beard is always attended or followed by a marked deterioration in the physical organization, not only of the existing race of people, but of the race to come.

Suddenly, they have become suspiciously silent on the subject. They eulogize France, they praise the gallantry of French soldiers, but they do not indulge any anticipations of the pleasures and advantages to be gained from an Imperial visit. Perhaps we can throw some little light upon the subject.

TOBBERS ARRESTED.--In Saltfleet, Canada West, two men stopped at the house of a farmer named DEAN, and after partaking of his hospitality, robbed him of some money and clothing, and decamped. Mr. DEAN aroused the neighbors, who gave chase and captured the ungrateful rogues: and at last accounts they were safely lodged in Hamilton jail.

A twofold murder of the most atrocious and determined character took place on Friday night, about 8 3/4 o'clock, in Warren-street, Fitzroy-square. The victims are--first, Mr. GEORGE MOORE, sodawater manufacturer, of No. 73 Warren street; and secondly, Mr. CHARLES COLLARD, green-grocer, of No. 74, in the same street, who, upon hearing a cry of " Murder!" in the adjoining nouse, ran out, and in an attempt to arrest the assassin was shot through the body.

FIRE EXTINGUISHMENT.--A fire in a furniture factory, at Peoria, Ill., was lately extinguished most effectually by opening the safety valve of the factory steam engine and letting the steam fill the building. The vapor suddenly and completely subdued the flames, and when the firemen arrived on the ground they found that their services were not needed.

A NEW KIND OF DUEL.--The New-Orleans Crescent says that a Frenchman, thinking his honor damaged by another Frenchman's insult, challenged the insulter to fight. The challenged having the choice of weapons, and standing in wholesome dread of "bullets and blades," as Bob Acres says, chose hoop-poles. course the fight came off with the selected tools, and the wounded honor of each was healed by having his body, head and shoulders badly bruised.

OVERSIGHT IN THE RECIPROCITY TREATY.--Quite an important omission in this treaty has been brought to our notice by the Portland Argus, in regard to the articles of molasses and sugar. The treaty does not provide for the admission of American grown molasses and sugar into the Provinces free of duty, and the consequence is, by the present tariffs, quite a discrimination against the American, products, and in favor of those imported from foreign countries.

BURTON'S THEATRE.--A melancholy squib in five acts, called a Comedy, and entitled "Pride Shall Have a Fall," was produced here last night, according to the play bill--for the first time in thirty years. It is to be regretted that its well merited repose has been invaded. The next time it is placed on the shelf, let us hope that it will permanently remain there.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times: On the first day of the year 1855, at the age of eighty-three years and twenty-one days, one among the last of the Pioneers of Ohio has gone to his final rest. SHAKSPEARE IN RUSSIA.-There are translations of some of SHAKSPEARE'S plays performed in Russia. The most frequently witnessed are "Hamlet" and " King Lear:" the class of shopkeepers, who may be called the people in Russia, for the others are mere serfs, are those by whom they are chiefly appreciated, and SHAKSPEARE is reverenced by most of them nearly as much as in England, although they have read his works only in a translation.

A River Thief Shot. At an early hour on Friday morning a band of river thieves boarded the brig Wasp, Captain SMITH, lying at the foot of Jay-street, Brooklyn, and proceeded to the cabin, where they made so much noise-as to arouse the Captain, who upon ascertaining their presence, took a pistol from near his berth and fired. The thieves left precipitately.

Messrs. ALDEN and EDDY's Pacific Telegraph bill was passed to-day in the Senate, as it came from the House, without amendent. Van Diemen's Land. AGRICULTURE.--The crops in this colony look well, especially in the western districts of the colony, where there is much rich and new land. The two Houses met in Joint Convention this morning, and resumed balloting for United States Senator with the following result: SIMON CAMERON, 55; BUCKALAW, 23; Scattering, 52. No choice. The above shows a slight falling off among CAMERON's friends--he having had 59 votes at the previous trial.

In the Senate yesterday the House bill to reduce and modify rates of postage was passed. One section of the bill requires the prepayment of letters, by stamps, after the first of January, 1856, and another provides for the registration of valuable letters.

The Annual Report of the Governors of the Alms-house is published. As usual, it is a document of portly dimensions and peculiar interest. The organization of the Board of Ten Governors has numbered six years; but in this brief space a very considerable amount of good has been accomplished.

By reference to our advertising columns it will be seen that a butting match is in contemplation between the steward of the Wild Pigeon and a ram celebrated for his strength and courage.

From the Baltimore Patriot of Friday Evening. The United States Marshal yesterday arrested Captain RAINES, on the charge of gross maltreatment of JOHN, alias THOMAS WHITE, the cook of the bark Nat Hooper, while on a voyage from New-Orleans to Baltimore.

We are in receipts of papers from Halifax, N. S., and St. John, N. B., of late dates. The Legislative Council of Nova Scotia has refused to pass the Prohibitory Liquor Law, deferring its consideration until the next session. The Halifax Journal contains official orders for providing rations for 500 recruits expected from the United States for the army in the Crimea.

Judge MORRIS, of the Supreme Court, by a decision in the case of Mrs. WADE, brought before him Saturday on a writ of habeas corpus, substantially declares all of the thirty arrests of the street women during the past week Illegal.

To-day has been mild and summer-like for the first time this Spring. The snow is rapidly disappearing and business exhibits considerable activity in preparations for the Spring trade. The ice in the Lake extends from the American to the Canadian shore as far up as the eye can reach, and it is the opinion of the best judges that there will be no opening of navigation till the 1st of May. y.

The Sunday Liquor law is most stringently enforced to-day, and not a single drinking shop has been open. The refectories confine their operations to the dispensing of edibles only. The new law regulating the Fire department went into operation last night; 54 companies have accepted its provisions, while 24 have rejected them and gone out of service.

Dies, at Canaan, March 14, 1855, JONATHAN GILLETT-aged ninety-three years and thirty-two days. This venerable man was a native of West Hartford. When nine years old he went to Lenox, and remained there seven years.

We have received a communication from one who writes intelligently, on the subject of complaints against the management of our Post-Offices. In a position to know, as nearly as is possible under the most favorable circumstances, the truth of the matter, he feels authorized to say, that of the aggregate of blunders in the delivery of letters, those who direct them are the cause of nearly one-half.

The returns from nearly thirty towns show that INGHAM, Democrat, leads all others for Governor. MINOR, Know-Nothing, leads DUTTON, Whig, very largely, and will fall but little short of INGHAM. There will be no election by the people.

LAWRENCE, of Boston, that the specimens of American Domestic Goods which he carried out with him on the Japan Expedition were distributed to the authorities and common people of Japan, by whom they were highly valued as being superior to the fabrics of similar material produced by native industry.

Yesterday morning, twenty-four of the women committed to Blackwell's Island as vagrants and prostitutes, were brought before Judge ROOSEVELT on habeas corpus, and their release demanded. His Honor first held, that, as the matter was brought before Justice MORRIS, the whole matter should be decided by him.

The result of to-day's election is not determined, but the Know-Nothings are probably ahead. Several serious rows have taken place during the afternoon, and it is reported that one American and two or three Germans have been killed.

Dust--wind--suffocation. These three words would stand in themselves for a weather item. A perfect hurricane has prevailed for two days and nights. The wind did not abate yesterday morning; nor did it die out last night. BOREAS, like SAM, was "around." The signs creaked ; shingles (up-country) flew ; dust blew ; the air was cold ; eyes were clean put out. And tides fell--fell very low.

On the Dedham Turnpike, in Roxbury, just beyond Oak-street, there is an ordinary house in which a school is kept by seven ladies, Catholic "Sisters of Charity," members of the order of Notre Dame. They have twelve pupils, young ladies between the ages of ten and fifteen, all Americans by birth.

It was a busy day in the Law Courts yesterday. Nine Capital cases were brought forward in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, and days of trial were assigned to them. A motion to quash the indictments against the parties indicted for the murder of POOLE, was argued at considerable length.

A perfect army of adult and juvenile vagrants has lately been organized in this City, for the purpose of removing the posters from the street corners as soon as they are put up, and disposing of the scraps to the manufacturers of papier macho.

The April term of the Court of Oyer and Terminer commenced yesterday morning, before Hon. Judge Cowles. MINOR, the Know-Nothing candidate, ranks next; and DUTTON, the candidate of the Whigs, lowest. In the Third Congressional District, DEAN, Know-Nothing and Whig, is elected by a large majority.

By the steamship Daniel Webster, at this port last night, we have dates from San Francisco to the 9th ult. None of the suspended Bankers had resumed payment, but the excitement had subsided. It was thought probable that none of the Bankers would resume payment except Messrs. PAGE, BACON CO.

It commenced snowing yesterday afternoon, and has continued till 2 o'clock this afternoon. It has proved about the worst snow of the season. The Oswego train due at 10 o'clock A. M., did not arrive till 7- P. M.

We have returns from Kansas showing the election of the pro-Slavery ticket at Bull Creek, Lawrence, Douglas, Doniphan, Tecumsch, Shawnee Mission, Leavenworth and Hooky Point, by majorities varying from 200 to 800. The election was conducted with tolerable quictude.

Arrived ship Herald, SLOCUM, from Ochotsk sea with 1,300 barrels oil and 7,000 pounds of bone. Has sold and sent home 350 barrels of sperm oil, 1,050 barrels of whale, and 28,000 pounds of bone. Also, arrived bark Clcora, SMITH, from the Pacific Ocean, with 1,200 barrels sperm oil.

There is an interesting slave case now before the Courts of Cincinnati. It is that of the slave girl ROSETTA. She was the property of a clergyman named DENNISON, who, wishing to send her from Kentucky to Virginia, entrusted her to the care of a friend. He, finding no boat at Cincinnati for Wheeling, was pleased to go on the railroad by way of Columbus.

WALLACK'S THEATRE.--A very agreeable petite comedy, called "The Diary of a Young Wife," was produced here last evening with success. It is adapted from the French piece, Les Memoires de Deux Jeunes Mariecs, and is one of those genteel little comediettas peculiarly suited for this company. The way it has been placed on the stage reflects the greatest credit on the management.

News from the city of Mexico is to the 17th, and from Vera Cruz to the 22d. During the latter part of February numerous earthquakes were felt in Mexico, Puebla, Jalisco, and Vera Cruz. General WOLL, the friend of SANTA'ANNA, had returned from his excursion to the South, having effected nothing.

The delivery of the girl ROSETTA by Judge PARKER, and the seizure of her by the United States Marshall ROBINSON, are known. At 9 o'clock on Tuesday morning, her guardian made affidavit as to the fact, declaring she had been forcibly arrested without due legal process, at the instance of DENNISON, and in contempt of the authority of this Court and of the laws of the State.

The House this morning was entirely engaged is discussing the bill to appoint Commissioners to select a site for a second Lunatic Asylum. The main point appeared to be, not the propriety of having a second institution, but a contest about where it should be located, which was supposed to turn upon the locality of the persons named as Commissioners.

It is quite generally known that the authorities at Washington are preparing a case upon which to ask of the Peruvian Government suitable indemnity to E. G. BENSON, of this City, for losses sustained by him, arising out of his unfortunate Lobos Island Guano speculation, and public attention is thus again drawn to the subject.

Our Community continues intensely excited. The cannon taken from the Germans yesterday by the Americans was quietly conveyed from the public landing this afternoon by the former. An immense number of people have assembled in Fifth-street Market-place. They have sent a Committee for the cannon, which had been taken to Freemason's Hall, and passed resolutions that if it is not delivered forthwith, they will go and take it.

The charter adopted for the government of Hoboken as a city provides for the election of the following officers: City Officers--A Director, a Treasurer, a Clerk, a Collector, a Collector of Arrears of Taxes, an Overseer of the Poor, a Superintendent of Common Schools, a Street Commissioner and a Pound Keeper.

The excitement in this city is on the increase. The Germans refused to give up the cannon, consequently fighting has commenced over the Canal, and it is reported several have been killed. The Germans are mostly armed, and fortified within houses, while the American party are also well prepared. The probability is, that matters will be measurably postponed until the morning, when it is hoped the present bitter feeling may have somewhat subsided.

The House passed to-day over the Governor's veto the following Bank bills: Freehold, Woodbury, Hunterdon and Perth Amboy Banks--all by a three-fifth vote. They are all new charters. The Hunterdon Bank is a change from the general to the special law.

To the Editor of the New-York Daily Times : The Code of Criminal Procedure reported to the Legislature of this State, by its 476th section provides that on the trial of an indictment for any other offence than a libel, questions of law are to be decided by the Court, and that the Jury are bound to receive as law what is laid down to them as such by the Court.

RIVERHEAD, Suffolk Co., Wednesday, April 4, 1855. The Know-Nothings nominated their ticket in this town and thought they should elect it. The Government of Brazil seems to have definitely determined that the great Amazon River shall not be opened to foreign navigation. If this decision is maintained, the immense valleys drained by this mighty stream and its numerous tributaries, and possessing elements of prosperity and wealth rarely excelled, must continue to be withheld from the uses and deprived of the benefits of commerce, and the arts of thorough civilization which follow commerce in its every track.

DEATH OF AN EDITOR.--Rev. MYRON TRACY, Editor of the Ohio Observer, and recently Secretary of the Western Reserve Agency of the Home Missionary Society, died in Hudson, Ohio, on Tuesday night, march 27. He was born in Hartford, Vermont, in April, 1798, and was nearly 57 years old at the time of his death. He was licensed to preach the gospel in 1835. In 1842 he was appointed to the Secretaryship which we have mentioned.

Dr. VERON, of Paris, ex-editor of the Constitutionnel, and ex-friend of LOUIS NAPOLEON, is a short of human stormy petrel--never so much in his proper element as when agitated to and fro in the tumult of a tempest. He commenced life as a druggist, but, having a soul above colocynth and assafoetida, became Director of the French Opera, by which he acquired notoriety and wealth.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--ROSSINI's "William Tell" will be repeated to-night for the fourth time. NIBLO'S GARDEN.--"Romeo et Julie" will be given to-night by the members of the German Opera Company. The great event of the astronomical world, the occultation of the planet Venus by the moon, was noticed last evening by gazing thousands. The moon approached rapidly after 8 o'clock P. M., growing visibly more luminous, until 8 1/2 o'clock, when Venus was totally obscured, and so remained until 10 o'clock. The phenomenon was of a very remarkable nature.

BROADWAY THEATRE.-Of the three Roman plays written by SHAKSPEARE, "Coriolanus" deals mostly with the masses, and from it we learn that the immortal bard was no tolerator of bread riots. The voxpopuli was not the vox dei in his estimation, but something of a less healthful and more offensive nature. The sovereign people, as depicted in this tragedy, is a vacillating, cowardly, time-serving crowd, good humored enough, but contemptible, in spite of joviality.

In the House this afternoon Governor GARDNER's veto of the Vermont and Massachusetts Railroad bill was sustained. the vote was Years 173; Nays 130--20 short of the required two-thirds. The motion to reconsider the bill will be aced on to-morrow.

THE FRUIT CROP.--Reports from all sections of the country concur generally in representing the prospect to be good for an abundant crop of fruit this season. The buds have been backward in putting out, and are thus insured against danger from frost. In many regions the peach trees which were reported dead in consequence of the severe frost of this winter, turn out only backward and are now full of promise.

From the American Medical Gazette. In the old Cathedral Church of Bremen is a vault, the atmosphere of which possesses the peculiar property of preserving from decay all bodies that may be placed therein. Visitors are shown eight human bodies, beside a number of cats, dogs, monkeys, birds, , all of which, by mere exposure to this atmosphere, have become dried and free from all offensive elliuvia; resembling in appearance, coarse parchment.

Under this head several journals yesterday published a paragraph relating to the printers employed on the Courier and Equirer, the errors in which require some notice. It is not true that "fourteen hands left on Friday night," nor is it true that the whole number of hands employed was "twenty-one." It is wise that any denial, "point-Wank" or other, was given to any demand, or that "waiting for copy" was formally complained of.

The steamer Keystone State, at this port from Savannah, reports, last night in Delaware Bay, was run into by the schooner Adrian, hence for Fall River, coal laden. The Adrian sunk in fifteen minutes. Three of her crew were saved, but GEORGE B. MALLET, the captain, and PRINCE A. LOVELL, the cook, were lost.

The City Inspector reports but 431 deaths in this City for the week ending on Saturday last, or which 268 were under 10 years of age. The British ship Bruiser has been converted into a complete flour mill, capable of grinding from 700 to 800 bushels of wheat per day--taking the raw material in at one end of the vessel, in the form of wheat, and turning it out at the other in well manufactured flour, without the intervention of manual labor.

We are informed that the Kansas Legislature will convene at Pawnee on the first Monday in July. So the time is near at hand for the people of this Territory to be represented. There will be an almost entire representation of Pro-Slavery freemen, and the true squatters of Kansas will be anxiously looking for the action of said body.

Amount of Wool Grown in Cape Colony and Australia.-From reliable data received at this Department, it appears that the quantity of Wool furnished by the Cape of Good Hope Colony from 1640 to 1852, inclusive, was 45,859,748 pounds; furnished by Australia during the same lime, 256,008.415 pounds; furnished by the Cape Colony during the year 1852, 7,773,505 pounds; furnihed by Australia during the same year, 32,500.000.

ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--Last evening VERDI'S admirable Opera of " Ernani" was played here for the first time by the La Grange Troupe. To speak of it in ordinary terms of satisfaction would be an injustice to the artistes. We will preface our remarks, therefore by saying that not withstanding some bemishes arising from hasty production, it was the most satisfying and perfect operatic performance we have witnessed at the Academy of Music.

A detailed account of the great Battle of Inkermann, on the 5th of November, has been published in Russia, and has found its way into the English papers. It contains nothing very new of the battle itself, and is chiefly interesting for its account of the Russian numbers actually engaged in the affair, and its apologies for the repulse and defeat.

At the meeting of the Jersey City Common Council, last evening, an ordinance was submitted regulating back drivers, carmon, cmnibus drivers, porters and runners--as those who solicit passengers are termed. Last night, as the mail train from New-York via New-Haven was nearing the city of Worcester, the engineer suddenly discovered an obstacle upon the track. It appears that the rails had been pried up, and five or six large stones and been placed underneath. By the force of the collision, the whole train was thrown from the track. The engine was thrown into a ditch.

The notorious HENRIETTA ROBINSON, convicted in the Renselaer County Court of the murder of TIMOTHY LANIGAN, was this afternoon sentenced by Judge HARRIS to be hung on the 3d of August next.
